{"step_by_step_thinking": "During a cochlear mastoidectomy, the surgeon removes the mastoid air cells to gain access to the middle ear and mastoid bone. The lateral semicircular canal is one of the three semicircular canals that are part of the inner ear. To identify the lateral semicircular canal during the procedure, the surgeon needs to locate the posterior wall of the external auditory canal. From there, they can trace the course of the canal. Looking at the provided options, it is clear that the arrow marked 'C' represents the lateral semicircular canal.", "answer_choice": "C"}
